Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2009 11:41PM TOB wrote: Kaeyreed, I may be wrong and hope that I am,but at least some of your symptoms sound somewhat like RSD (Reflex Sympathetic Dystrophy).  Over the years of my career, I saw a number of patients/clients with RSD following injury or a variety of surgical procedures.  Although rare following SNB, it can happen, but you certainly need a doctor to evaluate you and find out what is going on.  RSD is not well understood by the experts so don't expect just any doc to be able to tell you whether or not you have it.  A neurologist is probably where you will want to start. Check out http://www.lymphedemapeople.com/wiki/doku.php?id=reflex_sympathetic_dystrophy for more information regarding this very misunderstood condition.   Good luck and let us know what you find out.

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2009 05:19AM - edited Oct 21, 2009 05:20AM by TOB Shappy, I don't buy the whole bras cause BC thing, but some of what you say is true.  I've done many product liabilty cases involving defective drugs and medical devices, and the almighty dollar was always the primary motivator behind the marketing of these unsafe drugs and devices.  Some manufacturers faked their research testing data to gain FDA approval and the FDA was asleep at the switch in other cases.  Just because something has FDA approval does not guarantee safety.  Think DES in the 30's-50's, Thalidomide (1957-61) and more recently, Vioxx (recalled 2004 due to cardiac risks).  Hence the need for the FDA's Adverse Reaction Reporting System and drug recall orders.  That said, let's not forget that medical care in this country has also evolved into big business, sometimes driven more by a profit motive than patient wellbeing.  Some doctors get paid big bucks to test new drugs seeking FDA approval and others receive all kinds of perks ($$, trips, services) from drug companies seeking to increase the use of new drugs.  After all, drug company R&D is incredibly expensive and they have to make a profit before their patent expires and generics undercut their market share. I'll get off my soapbox with one additional comment.   I found your allegation that restless leg syndrome is a disease created by drug companies to sell drugs shocking.  Any competant neurologist or sleep disorder specialist will tell you that restless leg syndrome is a real neurological condition affecting thousands of people, including some on these boards with BC. It is not in their heads, they are not crazy and are not seeking attention. I would not have expected such an irresponsible comment from an RN.

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2009 10:29AM - edited Oct 22, 2009 10:30AM by TOB I fully understand the need to try and find a reason for one's cancer.  I have been agonizing over that question since I was first diagnosed. I don't have ANY family history, I have always tried to live a healthy lifestyle, I've always tried to be a good person, etc. etc. SO...Why me?  What did I do to deserve this?  What did I do to cause this?  I can't find an answer for my cancer so I have reached the same conclusion as Athena-Lionness.  Being alive causes all kinds of cancer.  Cancer in humans has existed as long as humans have inhabited the earth.  Is there more cancer now or did many cases go undocumented and undiagnosed before the advent of "modern medicine"?  I think that both are probably true.  Many cancers are primarily diseases of aging (which obviously still occur in some children and young people) and we simply live longer now than at any time in history.  Some folks have strong familiy histories of cancer, but the majority of cases are not familial.  All, however, are throught to start with a DNA mutation in a single cell.  What causes such mutations?  I truly believe that science will eventually prove that many but far from all cancers are explained by the damage that human activities and overpopulation have done to the earth/environment, by carcinogenic natural or manmade products (often in use for years before being identified as such) and by "modern" lifestyles (stress, dietary factors, increased obesity, couch potato-ism, etc.)  Cancers like mine that can't be traced to any particular cause may simply be the result of good old "S&%# Happens" (or if I was trying to be more PC) "when good things happen to bad people." Whatever the cause, all we can do is move forward, one step at a time, one day at a time, making decisions that work for us.  I went braless through my waif stage in the late 60's and 70's, but it is just plain physically painful for me now, and I find it to be age inappropriate now that I'm older, a bit heavier and much bustier.  So... I'm moving forward still wearing my lacy, underwire bras until the day of my surgery and resuming their use as soon as possible thereafter. (Yes, it is fine with my docs.) Small things make a real difference in the quality of life and lacy underwear makes me feel good. I'd rather risk another cancer than wear what I call "orthopedic underwear"!

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2009 04:15PM TOB wrote: Rosiesmom, I know how a SNB (sentinal node biopsy) is performed, but since I won't have one until 11/19, I will leave the answer to that part of your question to others who have gone before us. What I can tell you is that SNB in patients with DCIS continues to be a source of disagreement in the literature and in practice. The risk of complications from SNB is low, but complications such as lymphedema, seroma, infection and sensory neuropathy have been reported after the procedure. When I was just going to have a lumpectomy, SNB was not considered to be necessary unless the pathology revealed microinvasion. After reading the literature, I understood why. By definition DCIS is contained within the milk ducts, and cannot therefore, metastasize to the lymph nodes.  That can change, however, in those cases where DCIS has invaded or broken through the wall of the milk ducts and into the surrounding breast tissue. Neither of the path reports from my 2 lumpectomies indentified any microinvasion, so another procedure to do sentinal node mapping and excision was not performed.  Now that I will be having a mastectomy, they are going to do a SNB, primarily because sentinal node mapping cannot be performed after a mastectomy has been done.  The finding of lymph node metastasis in pure breast DCIS (without microinvasion) is not unknown, but is a very rare occurence if the primary tumour has been completely excised and microinvasion has been ruled out by a thorough histologic examination by an experienced pathologist.  It is done in conjunction with a mastectomy to insure that occult metastases are not missed.  The chance they will find anything is quite low, but if you have to go through such an extensive procedure for Stage 0 cancer, knowing that they got it all and there is no occult disease identified will help you sleep at night.
